title: On NTSB recommendations, FAA closes helicopter route near DC airport weeks after tragedy
author: MENNATALLA IBRAHIM Capital News Service
content: The National Transportation Safety Board issued urgent safety recommendations, warning that helicopter flights near Reagan National pose serious risks and urging the FAA to close a four‑mile stretch over the Potomac when runway 15/33 is in use; “Urgent recommendations require immediate action to prevent similar accidents or incidents when we issue them,” NTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy said, adding, “We believe a critical safety issue must be addressed without delay.” Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy accepted the recommendations on behalf of the FAA, stating, “We’re in a situation where we’re threading the needle, allowing helicopters to fly down the same airspace as landing aircraft,” and questioning, “And why this information wasn’t studied and known before January 29 is an important question.” Duffy has limited helicopter traffic through the end of March, is coordinating with Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth on alternate military routes, and pledged to overhaul the “antiquated” air‑traffic‑control system, saying, “We’re at a point where we can do this fast—three and a half to four years for a brand new air traffic control system. Gold plated. Envy of the world,” and, “It will greatly improve our safety…but it’s also going to improve the efficiency that we have in American air travel, which I think will mean less delays, less cancellations, and again, better safety.” The NTSB’s preliminary report, released with the recommendations, cites more than 15,000 near‑collisions between commercial aircraft and helicopters at the airport from October 2021 to December 2024 but does not yet assign a probable cause; Homendy said, “We still have a lot of work to do in this investigation, so the report contains only the facts that we’re able to validate and release at this time,” and, “The easiest and quickest part of the investigation is determining what happened. The part that takes longer is the how and why.” Homendy reassured travelers, stating, “I just flew with my daughter out of DCA…aviation is incredibly safe,” and adding, “However, there are safety issues and areas where we need to improve to make sure that we are at zero.”

title: Oxford to install three-way stop on Tilghman Street - Town considering traffic study to address speeding concerns
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content: Oxford will install a three‑way stop at Tilghman and Bank Streets to address speeding, with installation expected in the next few weeks. Resident Will Cawley presented 13‑day speed data showing 73 violations out of 3,225 vehicles, a maximum of 36 mph, and advocated for a speed‑study and temporary speed‑feedback signs. Commission President Tom Costigan said, “I think the first step really is to put up a stop sign at Tilghman and Bank,” adding, “A three‑way stop. Let’s see if that works.” Cawley said, “Once the speed study is done, then we can reevaluate what the recommendations are and see if we can make some changes to get the speed lowered.” Costigan also noted, “It’s not an easy process,” and, “But it’s one we can certainly look into and try,” and later added, “And who knows,” he said. “They may even like it.”

title: September declared National Preparedness Month
content: The Talbot County Council proclaimed September National Preparedness Month, presenting the proclamation to Emergency Services director Brian LeCates and Emergency Management chief Geneva Schaffle. Schaffle emphasized the timing, saying, “We are approaching hurricane season, and this week has been very active, so we thought it was a great time to remind the community the importance of preparedness,” and added, “Our county works really hard with all of our stakeholders to prepare all year long but there are a couple of things people can do to be prepared.” She also urged residents to review insurance, noting, “This is also the time to pull out your insurance policies, know what is in your insurance policy and make sure you are prepared for our storm season as we come to a peak here in September.” County Manager Clay Stamp said, “An informed community is a strong community,” and warned, “The key is to connect with Emergency Services today, on a sunny day, so that when the storm clouds come in, you are connected and get timely information and we can respond to help.” The Department of Emergency Services directed citizens to ready.gov, talbotalerts.com, and the DES website for resources, while Planning and Zoning offers a Community Rating System for flood‑insurance discounts, and DES will host a seven‑week Community Disaster Response Course with three spots remaining.

title: Toddlers drown in incident in Greensboro on Sunday
author: STAFF REPORT
content: Two toddlers—a 2‑year‑old boy and a 3‑year‑old boy—drowned in Greensboro on June 29, prompting a response from Caroline County deputies at about 7:30 p.m. Emergency personnel from the Caroline County Department of Emergency Services and the Greensboro Volunteer Fire Department treated the children on site before they were taken to Shore Regional Health in Easton, where both later died. The Caroline County Sheriff's Office Criminal Investigation Division is investigating the incident, and the agency was assisted by Maryland State Police, the county’s State Attorney’s Office, and other local services. “The Caroline County Sheriff's Office extends its deepest condolences to the family and all those affected by this heartbreaking tragedy,” the press release said.

title: Dundalk residents view crumpled bridge with shock, dismay
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content: A container ship slammed into the Francis Scott Key Bridge just before 1:30 a.m. Tuesday, causing the structure to collapse into the Patapsco River, with six construction workers presumed dead and two rescued. Residents who had crossed the bridge earlier, like Teresita Santana, felt their house tremble and said, “As if something had exploded,” and later added, “It was scary because it could have been us.” On the hill overlooking the wreckage, many expressed “Shock and dismay,” and Judy Corkhum said, “Nobody in a million years thought we would wake up this morning to something like that,” adding, “It brings back emotions from 9/11. ... You saw that and the first thing you think is, 'Oh my god. The people. The workers.'” Anthony Meeks noted, “The Key Bridge is a very iconic piece of Dundalk,” and warned, “It (will) make me go out of my way to find a different path to get to where I need to go,” also saying, “Because it's like you don't really expect these kinds of tragedies and stuff to happen and occur in your neighborhood.” Historical Society Vice President Joe Stadler remarked, “It takes a while to fathom it,” while Corkhum lamented, “I’m so used to seeing that pretty view out there every day,” as the community grappled with the loss of a landmark.

title: Cambridge man handed two life sentences without parole
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content: Tramelle Williams, 23, of Cambridge was sentenced to two consecutive life terms without parole for the December 2022 murders of 24‑year‑old Taijay Daniels and 69‑year‑old Lory Fields, and received three additional consecutive 20‑year sentences for robbery and firearms charges. Dorchester County Administrative Judge William Jones called surveillance footage of Daniels’ death “possibly in the top five, if not No. 2 most difficult thing I’ve had to see,” denied a motion for a new trial, and said jurors were instructed to disregard unrelated evidence, noting “And they did.” The state’s response to the motion asserted that “‘Taijay Daniels’ would be nothing more than a ‘John Doe’ to the seated jurors.” At the sentencing hearing Williams apologized to the victims’ families while maintaining his innocence. Daniels’ mother, Barbara Gabbin, called her son a giver, saying he was “full of love” and adding, “Taijay was my world.” Fields’ daughter, Lauren Davis, read a letter in which she said, “I have been so lost without you,” and later added, “I would give anything for just one more day, one more second with him.”

title: Cambridge man charged with kidnapping in connection to missing woman
author: Natalie Jones
content: Kenneth Stefan Bradley, 41, of Cambridge was arrested on Feb. 19 in Anne Arundel County and charged with kidnapping, assault and related offenses in connection with the disappearance of 31‑year‑old Tiyavauna Britt, who remains missing. Britt’s car was found unlocked with her belongings inside, and a note in the driver’s side door read, “No phones, no kids, just us.” Police placed both Britt’s and Bradley’s phones in downtown Cambridge and Great Marsh Park on Feb. 7, and surveillance captured a dark Chevrolet Suburban with a Black male exiting the vehicle with a woman whose hands appeared bound, accompanied by audio of loud thuds. Bradley, who is on probation for a 2022 second‑degree assault conviction stemming from prior domestic‑violence incidents with Britt, failed to verify completion of a required abuser‑intervention program, prompting a violation report on Feb. 16. He is being held without bond and is scheduled for a preliminary hearing in Dorchester County District Court on March 12, while authorities continue to seek information on Britt’s whereabouts.

title: Police Team With Talbot Optimist Club For Shop With A Cop
author: Contributed
content:
On Dec. 9, the Easton Police Department, Oxford Police Department and Talbot County Sheriff’s Office teamed with the Talbot Optimist Club for its annual “Shop with a Cop” event at the Elks Lodge in East on.  
Debbie Henckel, the event’s long‑time organizer, said, “It’s all about the kids, the smiles on their faces, and them being able to have something to give to their families.”  
After being paired with officers, the children rode squad cars to Easton Walmart, where they used their allocated budgets to buy holiday gifts for their families, often spending the entire amount on others.  
Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey said, “This is a good place we live in.” He continued, “I’ve seen these kids looking out for their families instead of themselves, our officers reaching into their own wallets to make sure no one is left out, and even just some local townspeople going out of their way to do the same. It is really moving, and I’m proud to see it all.”  
Henckel noted, “You see a lot of returning officers and you know that’s because they care. It’s nice to see their eagerness to be here with the kids,” and added, “They really make a difference to these kids, and around our community.”  
She also said, “ To have their support over the years means more than you know,” thanking the Elks Lodge, Walmart and the police departments for their continued assistance.

title: Demolition of remaining Key Bridge structures beginning around July 7
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@chespub.com
content: The Maryland Transportation Authority announced that demolition of the remaining Key Bridge structures will begin on or about July 7 and is expected to take several months. The work will start with removing the bridge deck over the river, then dismantling sections at Hawkins Point and Sollers Point, followed by removal of barriers, parapets, girders, piers and the original north and south abutments, all without controlled detonations. Heavy equipment—including excavators, concrete saws, vacuums, cranes, trucks and on‑site concrete crushers—will be used, and barges will provide protective shielding for waterway users. Noise from typical large‑construction activities is anticipated from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m., and equipment is being installed to capture baseline noise and vibration data before demolition begins. The authority is seeking permit modifications to reflect updated bridge alignment and design changes, and it will continue to issue notices and updates to ensure safety for nearby communities, roads and waterways.

title: Accessible AED added in Downtown Easton
author: Contributed
content: The first 24‑hour publicly accessible automatic external defibrillator (AED) in downtown Easton is now operational, installed on Washington Street next to Doc’s Downtown Grille through a partnership between Talbot CARES and Bluepoint Hospitality. “We are incredibly proud of this station. It's the first time we've been able to place a station that is accessible 24 hours a day, outside of a public park or recreation area,” said Rachael Cox, special programs paramedic for DES, adding “By placing it in a prominent location downtown, we are hoping that this important resource will be utilized in emergencies by the surrounding community.” Bluepoint Hospitality funded the cabinet and power, while Talbot Paramedic Foundation supplied the AED and Talbot Emergency Services will stock and check the unit. “One of our priorities is for visitors and residents to feel safe downtown,” said Michael Smith, head of security at Bluepoint Hospitality, who noted “As part of this initiative, many Bluepoint staffers were certified in CPR, First Aid, AED and Stop the Bleed this year. We hope other downtown businesses join in on the efforts. The more staff that is certified, the better we can serve individuals with life‑saving techniques before the professionals arrive.” The AED is part of Talbot CARES’ countywide effort that has placed over 200 devices in various public locations.

title: Plane crashes during landing at Bay Bridge Airport
author: Staff Writer
content: A four‑seat Cirrus aircraft crashed while landing at Bay Bridge Airport in Stevensville, veering off the runway into a marshy area and coming to rest partially in water. Beth Malasky, the county’s public information manager, said the sole occupant was not injured despite the aircraft’s significant damage. Local fire departments and EMS cleared the scene shortly after noon, and federal and state aviation authorities are conducting a standard investigation. Malasky added there is no damage to the runway; however, the airport will remain closed until the investigation is complete.

title: 2 charged with hindering drug investigation, reporting fake shooting in Easton
author: Konner Metz
content: Police in Easton arrested Elon Black, 38, of Easton, and Lacira Wilson, 39, of Worton, for hindering a drug investigation after they allegedly made a false 911 call reporting a shooting at the Easton Walmart. During an April 4 traffic stop on U.S. Route 50 and Cecil Drive, a K‑9 search found a “suspected heroin/fentanyl mix,” crack cocaine and ecstasy in Black’s vehicle. Investigators say Black called Wilson, who then placed the bogus emergency call, prompting officers to check the Walmart where no shots were found. Both defendants were arrested on Sept. 18‑19 on charges of intent to distribute drugs, obstructing and hindering, and making false statements, each posting a $10,000 unsecured bond. Wilson’s trial is set for Nov. 5 and Black’s for Nov. 3 in Talbot County District Court, with Black also facing additional felony and misdemeanor counts slated for a Dec. 8 jury trial.

title: Gallatin County Sheriff's Office welcomes public to tour new building at Four Corners
author: Laurenz Busch Chronicle Staff Writer
content:
Sheriff Dan Springer hosted a public tour of the new 25,000‑square‑foot Gallatin County Sheriff's Office building in Four Corners on Dec. 18, 2024, moving the office from the detention center to a site off Laura Louise Lane.  
The $5.4 million, 6.48‑acre property, bought in 2020 and remodeled for cost‑effectiveness, includes three shooting ranges, space for patrol units, detectives and the Missouri River Drug Task Force.

title: 2-structure fire causes $850,000 in damage
author: Tom McCall
content: On August 21, firefighters responded to a two‑structure, two‑alarm blaze on Stone Boundary Road in Cambridge, Maryland, that destroyed a former butcher shop and the adjacent wooden‑frame farmhouse. No deaths or injuries were reported, but the combined loss of the buildings was estimated at $600,000 and the contents at $250,000, for a total damage cost of about $850,000. Seventy‑five firefighters worked for three hours, and the Tanker Task Force was called in for additional water, according to a release from the State Fire Marshal’s office. According to the fire marshal's report, "The fire originated inside the butcher shop shortly after the owner had been doing work inside. Embers from this fire landed on the cedar shingles of the vacant nearby 100+ year old home eventually spreading to the remainder of the house. Both structures are considered a total loss." Investigators noted that there were no smoke alarms present.

title: Officer fights to deter drivers like one who injured him
author: LYDIA HURLEY Capital News Service
content: Less than four months after a reckless driver struck him on Interstate 270, Montgomery County Sgt. Patrick Kepp had both legs amputated and is undergoing daily rehabilitation at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center. Determined to prevent similar attacks, Kepp announced he will travel to Annapolis to testify on two proposed reckless‑driving bills, saying, “When I was brought into the conversation about new laws being created, right away, I knew it was something I wanted to do.” He added, “I will be there in Annapolis to make sure these bills happen.” The legislation would broaden Maryland’s definition of reckless and negligent driving, increase penalties, and require court appearances, which County Executive Marc Elrich explained is needed because “It’s way too easy for a driver to just pay a fine and get back on the road and do what they were doing before.” Del. Greg Wims (D‑Montgomery) called the proposal “I’m going to call it the Sgt. Pat Kepp Bill on Reckless Driving,” calling Kepp a “hero,” while Kepp said the measures will “give a little more teeth to some of our laws” and “will strengthen our laws and make our roadways safer,” noting the goal is not mass jail time but to stop repeat offenders, and Elrich warned, “All it takes is a moment’s loss of control over that vehicle,” adding, “Instead of being entertaining, it would take little to transform it into a deadly incident.”

title: CPR training for 911 calls could expand statewide
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content: Tony Rose, the chief of 911 for Charles County, received unanimous county‑commissioner approval on Feb. 28 to travel to Annapolis and testify in support of House Bill 1092, which would require the Maryland 911 Board to set training standards for telecommunications CPR and expand the 911 Trust Fund to fund such training. “When an out‑of‑hospital cardiac emergency occurs, you have about 600 seconds — 10 minutes — to make a difference to save a life before irreversible brain death occurs,” Rose said. He explained that the county’s new program mandates a virtual training scenario every three months, and “the results have been phenomenal,” adding that it has “doubled, and in some cases tripled, the number of survivors of out‑of‑hospital cardiac arrest in Charles County.” A written testimony from Rose noted that bystander CPR rose from 27% to 43%, AED use increased from 23.5% to 28.6%, and hospital discharges grew from five to eleven. “It reminds me of an incident when I used to coach soccer,” Commissioner Ralph E. Patterson II (D) said, recalling a cardiac‑arrest call where the operator’s calm guidance underscored the need for the legislation. Rose concluded that “currently, Charles County is the only jurisdiction that participates in this program,” and the bill would make similar training mandatory for all 911 centers.

title: Mid-Shore sheriffs join in call for DJS secretary's resignation
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content: Mary sheriffs from Dorchester, Talbot, Caroline and the majority of other counties voted to have the Maryland Sheriffs’ Association ask Gov. Wes Moore to “immediately demand the resignation” of Department of Juvenile Services secretary Vincent Schiraldi. The letter the association sent reads, “Since Schiraldi’s appointment in 2022, his extreme policies and lack of leadership as the Secretary of the Department of Juvenile Services, have directly made communities less safe in Maryland,” and adds, “Consistently in Maryland, juveniles have been charged with serious violent crimes … only to be turned right back over to a parent or guardian, and back out on the streets to commit more crimes.” Moore’s office highlighted a “26% decline in juvenile homicide arrests and 46% decline in non‑fatal shootings of juveniles” and stated, “The governor is fully committed to working with local elected officials, law enforcement, the judiciary, and community leaders to improve public safety by holding youth accountable and rehabilitating them,” without directly addressing the resignation request. Schiraldi told WBAL‑TV, “Gov. Moore has been extremely supportive,” adding, “He’s gotten us additional funds this year — $17 million to make community safer by expanding programs — and I want those community members who are calling for my resignation to feel safe.” Sheriffs criticized the secretary, with Dorchester Sheriff James Phillips saying he “lost all respect” for Schiraldi and that “The law‑abiding citizens are suffering because of their ignorance and stupidity in protecting these criminals,” Talbot Sheriff Joe Gamble asserting, “They’re getting more community service and stuff out of Teen Court than they would ever get out of DJS,” and Caroline Sheriff Donnie Baker calling the situation a “shame when parental rights are superseded by the legislature.”

title: For All Seasons gives update on human trafficking in Talbot County
author: Konner Metz
content: Representatives from For All Seasons told Talbot County Council that human trafficking remains a problem locally, with Vice President of Strategy and Development Lauren Weber stating, “It is happening and it's happening here. That continues to be the case,” Weber said. “ … There's a complexity to human trafficking that it doesn't really know county boundaries.” Vice President of Marketing and Communications Katie Theeke added, “We know that human trafficking knows no boundaries and that it affects people of different backgrounds, races, genders,” Theeke said. “We have seen several cases come through our doors, and it comes from Talbot County. It comes from neighboring counties. We really aim to be the connector to get those people the help that they need.” When asked about trends, Weber described the situation as a “double‑edged sword” and said, “A year ago we sat in front of you and said, when we look at our rape crisis center data, a good fifth of what was coming in was having at least one indicator of human trafficking,” Weber said. “ … That persists.” She also noted a shift in reporting, saying, “The folks that are self‑referring, we're seeing a decline,” she said. “But we're seeing a real rapid incline in folks coming to us and saying, ‘Hey, I know more and now I've seen something.’” Since September, more than 120 people have taken the organization’s free online anti‑human‑trafficking course, and council members presented a proclamation naming January National Human Trafficking Awareness Month. Council Vice President Pete Lesher concluded, “We know that even one victim is too many,” Lesher said. “We appreciate all that you do both on prevention, but also to develop and take care of those who have been victims.”

title: Man gets five years for Thanksgiving Day stabbing of stepson
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content: Ernest Anthony Vuocolo, 64, was sentenced to five years in prison for second‑degree assault after stabbing his 41‑year‑old stepson following a Thanksgiving dinner in November 2023, according to Cecil County Circuit Court records. Judge Cameron A. Brown imposed a maximum ten‑year term, suspended all but four years, added a consecutive one‑year sentence for carrying a dangerous weapon with intent to injure, a concurrent four‑year reckless endangerment sentence, and three years of supervised probation after release. The victim told investigators that he confronted Vuocolo about alleged “sexual comments” regarding his wife and was attacked, saying Vuocolo held him in a headlock and stabbed him in the chest; deputies at the scene reported the victim was “bleeding heavily” from his left side. Police said they responded to a complaint about a “physical domestic involving a knife,” recovered a six‑inch “thick blade” knife that was later described at trial as “field clever,” and treated Vuocolo for chest pain before returning him to custody. A jury convicted Vuocolo of the three charges but acquitted him of first‑degree assault, the most serious charge, with Assistant State’s Attorney Gavin Patashnick prosecuting and defense attorneys Tina Harris Schlecker and C. Thomas Brown representing him.

title: 'End of Watch'
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Bay Times Record Observer
content: The Fallen Heroes Memorial, observed each Feb. 13 for the past 22 years, was held Feb. 13, 2024 at Centreville United Methodist Church in Centreville, Maryland, hosted by the Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 108. Sheriff Gary Hoffman led the Pledge of Allegiance and a moment of silence, after which Senior Pastor Rev. Karen Handy welcomed families and community members. Former Lodge 108 president and deputy Chase Armington opened the ceremony, saying, "Tonight, we gather to honor our fallen heroes. It is our duty to never forget them, for they have paved the path forward with their lives. The path leading us here tonight was born from tragedy. Incredible losses. Unbearable pain for our families, friends, and the community. These honored in front of you served our community with pride, dignity, and honor. Knowing their lives could, at any moment be taken, so that we may live. So that we may continue on the path they have now paved." Mother of a fallen officer, Sue Nickerson, recalled her loss, stating, "The FOP from QAC started (this event) and they will always have it on February 13, the night that Michael (Nickerson) and Jason (Schwenz, Queen Anne's County deputy) were killed. But, it's to honor all emergency people who have passed away in the line of duty from Queen Anne's County," and added, "It means a lot. It really does. QAC is willing to step up, and support the families, and acknowledge the jobs that our law enforcement, our firefighters and our EMTs have done. It is very much appreciated." County State’s Attorney Lance Richardson reflected, "The heroes we celebrate tonight were tragically taken from us. We don't have any control over that. But what we do have control over is how we respond to it, how we react, how we pick up the pieces and go on. Stoicism also places an emphasis on appreciating the unity and precious gift of life," while a radio transmission announced, "Today we honor the memory and pay tribute to those who greatly served and protected QAC and the State of Maryland. May their dedication and sacrifice never be forgotten and may they rest in eternal peace," and Rev. Handy closed with a prayer, "Lord, you gave them the gift of courage of serving others. Lord, mend those hearts that are broken in the loss of these loved ones. Lord, we pray that this memorial tonight has brought a bit of peace. Lord, we lift up and thank you for each of these persons. We thank you and pray for those that they have left behind."

title: Cambridge man gets 25 years after taking plea deal in murder trial
author: STAFF REPORT
content: Daeveon Johnson, 19, was sentenced on Sept. 6 to 25 years in the Patuxent Youthful Offenders Program for the 2021 fatal shooting of Ja’Len Woolford after entering an Alford plea to first‑degree murder in November 2022. The sentence, which is retroactive to his Jan. 4, 2022 arrest, includes five years of probation, makes him eligible for parole after serving half, and orders him to have no contact with Key’Marion Ennals, who was acquitted of all related charges. Johnson testified at Ennals’s trial, and his initial police interview admitted he was carrying a .40‑caliber firearm, matching the weapon that killed Woolford. Dorchester County State’s Attorney Amanda Leonard said, “The State recommended a sentence of life imprisonment, suspending all but forty years of active incarceration,”. She added, “The Court heard heartfelt victim impact statements from three members of the victim’s family, each expressing their choice to forgive Mr. Johnson, and each requesting the Court consider a lesser period of active incarceration for Mr. Johnson given his cooperation and remorse.” Leonard concluded, “The State continues to offer condolences to all family and loved ones impacted by the loss of Ja’Len Woolford, and thanks the Court for its mindful consideration of all circumstances at sentencing.”

title: Crane accident at power substation leaves much of Caroline County without power Thursday
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content: On Thursday morning a commercial‑vehicle fire at a Delmarva Power substation in Denton knocked out power for more than 1,100 customers in Caroline County. content: At the July 7 town meeting, Federalsburg Mayor Kim Abner announced that Police Chief Joseph Gasser resigned effective June 25, saying, “The mayor and council would like to announce the resignation of Chief Gasser from the Federalsburg Police Department effective June 25,” and, “We want to thank Chief Gasser for his service to the town and wish him well on his future endeavors.” Sheriff Donald Baker said he was asked to assume day‑to‑day operations, adding, “I was contacted by the mayor and council and asked to take over day‑to‑day operations and management oversight of the department,” and, “I agree to do that on an interim basis for 30 to 60 days until the mayor and council decide what they are going to do moving forward and what that looks like for the Federalsburg Police Department.” Baker also noted that “everything is on the table to include signing an MOU somewhat like Ridgley's, directly with the sheriff's office of the county,” and, “Again, everything is on the table. and we are really early in this stage, but we absolutely could absorb any officers that were left.” The mayor scheduled a public forum for July 21 at 6 p.m. to discuss the town’s policing options. Gasser, a former military member, had served the town for nearly 30 years after being appointed chief in January.

title: Fire causes $1 million in damage to pizzeria
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content: A blaze at Mario’s Pizza in the Cherry Hill area near Elkton caused an estimated $1 million in damage, forcing the longtime pizzeria to close indefinitely, according to the Maryland Office of the State Fire Marshal. A neighboring employee called 911 at 9:57 p.m. on Tuesday after discovering the fire in the unit block on Beauchamp Road. Approximately 75 firefighters from several volunteer fire companies, with Singerly Volunteer Fire Company of Elkton serving as the on‑scene command unit, battled the blaze for about 20 minutes before bringing it under control. The fire caused roughly $600,000 in structural damage to the building and destroyed about $400,000 in property inside the shop, and a MOSFM spokesperson confirmed that no one was injured. The spokesperson also identified Mario Testa as the owner of the pizzeria.

title: Trams takes helm as Greensboro police chief
author: Connie Connolly
content: Mayor David Spencer administered the oath of office to new Greensboro Police Chief Lenox Trams shortly after 6 p.m. on Thursday, Jan. 4, at the Greensboro Community Center and Fire Hall, following Trams’s appointment on Dec. 11. Trams, 48, brings a 25‑year law‑enforcement career and joined the Greensboro Police Department in March 2023; he said, “(Chief Paugh) did a lot of work to get us up to standards,” and added, “We want the best officers who can do the job that the town deserves,” indicating a plan to add three more officers. Former colleagues from the Easton Police Department, including former EPD chief David Spencer, Oxford Police Chief Eric Kellner, and former Greensboro chief Lt. George Paugh, were present to applaud the swearing‑in. Sgt. Al Orrison recalled that Trams “offered me his trademark strong handshake and ‘took me under his wing.’ My kids actually call him Uncle Lenox. I love this man,” noting that Trams “always has compassion for everyone. He treats everybody fairly, and he's just an incredible human being.” Sgt. David Trevino praised Trams’s “endless energy” and said he “never stops giving to people” through mentoring and volunteer work.

title: Local K-9 units work to overcome retirements from cannabis law
author: Konner Metz
content: After Maryland legalized recreational cannabis in July 2023, many K‑9s trained to sniff marijuana were forced into early retirement, prompting agencies statewide to rebuild their units with dogs trained for other tasks. In Easton, the new black lab K‑9 Knox, certified in drug detection and working toward tracking certification, has already been deployed 17 times in Q1 2025, making six drug arrests alongside handler Pfc. Mark Schinault, who noted, “She has that drive for her reward, her toy after she does a good scan,” Schinault said. Lt. Tim Larrimore described the effort as a “complete rebuild” and said, “This odor of marijuana was enough before 2023 to give us probable cause to search. Now that’s out,” Larrimore said, emphasizing the continued importance of dogs for detecting substances humans cannot smell. Sheriff Joe Gamble of Talbot County echoed concerns about courtroom challenges, stating, “I really didn’t want to go down the road because I didn’t want to be challenged in the courtroom,” and Kent County Sgt. Scott Lockerman added, “Most of the agencies were able to replenish the dogs,” Lockerman said. Community outreach remains a priority, with Sgt. Steve Twilley noting, “Next thing you know, that kid’s come to you for help instead of lashing out or doing something at school,” and Sheriff James Phillips asserting, “I think an agency that’s trying to do today’s police work and doesn’t have the K‑9 ability out there, I don’t think they’re a full police agency,” Phillips said.

title: Three arrested in connection with death of Centreville teen
author: Staff Writer
content: Queen Anne's County Sheriff’s Office arrested 19‑year‑old Kamryn Andrews, 20‑year‑old James Lawson and 27‑year‑old Travis Lissau in connection with the June 1, 2025 shooting death of 19‑year‑old Christopher Parsley in Centreville. Detectives from the Sheriff's Office Criminal Investigation Unit worked with multiple federal, state and local partners, and a grand jury returned indictments before arrest warrants were issued on Oct. 6. Andrews is charged with two counts of attempted second‑degree murder, manslaughter, numerous assault and firearm offenses; Lawson and Lissau face similar charges, each also charged with conspiracy to alter physical evidence and possession of a firearm without a serial number. Sheriff Gary Hofmann said, “This has been an incredibly difficult time for Chris' family and for our entire community. The effects of this tragedy have been deeply felt, and our thoughts remain with those who continue to grieve. This investigation reflects the strength of collaboration between our community and our law enforcement partners.” He added, “As the investigation continues, every tip, video, and witness account remains vital to bringing closure for Chris's family and our community. We have zero tolerance for crime in Queen Anne's County and will always stand up for victims who no longer have a voice.” All three suspects are being held without bond while investigators continue to seek information from the public.

title: Federalsburg workshops agreement with Caroline County Sheriff's Office
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content: The Federalsburg Town Council held a special meeting to consider a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) that would have the Caroline County Sheriff’s Office assume policing duties for the town, replacing the Federalsburg Police Department. The draft agreement would assign four officers—a former town police sergeant, two police‑academy cadets and one sheriff’s deputy—to Federalsburg for a one‑year contract at a cost of about $863,000, roughly $280,000 less than the current $1.146 million police budget. Council members said the town would retain its police vehicles, cover gas, maintenance and a $15,000 uniform line item, while the sheriff’s office would handle criminal press releases and the town would manage event releases. "We felt as we wanted to give this MOU situation a try for a year, and throughout that year we want to have quarterly meetings with the public," Council Member Brandy James said at an Aug. 3 meeting. The council plans to move forward after Town Attorney Lyndsey Ryan revises the agreement for clarity.

title: Cambridge, Queen Anne's County receive MDOT grants
content: The Maryland Department of Transportation announced that 17 counties and municipalities will receive more than $28 million in FY 2023 Safe Streets and Roads for All grants, a federal program aimed at achieving the state’s Vision Zero goal of eliminating traffic fatalities and serious injuries by 2030. “In order to create the transportation system that Marylanders deserve, we must work with our citizens, our local officials and our Congressional delegation with unity and focus to deliver safe, equitable access across the state for everyone, whether they drive, ride, or walk,” Gov. Wes Moore said. “These grants help us achieve that goal and help fulfill our mission to lift every community.” Maryland Transportation Secretary Paul Wiedefeld added, “The Maryland Department of Transportation is proud to have worked closely with our federal delegation to support our local partners' efforts to receive more than $28 million in funding to boost safety for those who bike, walk and drive on our roads,” and added, “The Maryland Department of Transportation looks forward to working with local leaders throughout the state to put this money to use to reduce roadway fatalities and ensure our streets are safer for all Marylanders.” The City of Cambridge received a $320,000 grant for research on safer, more pedestrian‑friendly streets, and Mayor Stephen Rideout said, “We have a number of streets and intersections that are really quite dangerous, especially to pedestrians,” adding, “We’re grateful for the funding. It’s the kind of thing small communities need.” Queen Anne’s County was awarded $280,000 for a comprehensive multimodal safety plan, with Commissioner Jim Moran stating, “This federal grant will help our local, state and federal partners combine knowledge and resources to create a comprehensive highway safety plan that will improve safety for our citizens and everyone traveling though Queen Anne's county.”

title: Train and tractor-trailer collide in Hurlock accident
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content: A collision between a corn‑laden tractor‑trailer and a train on Nealson Street at Broad Street in Hurlock closed the streets Friday; the accident is under investigation and no injuries were reported. Leon Guin, a jockey driver at Amick Farms, said he saw the crash moments after it occurred, noting, “Our security guards heard the accident,” he said, “and two of our outside drivers saw and heard it also. They were bringing the chickens in at that time.” He described the truck cab and front of the trailer wrapped around the train and the corn spilling onto the tracks. Cathrin Banks, President and General Counsel for Maryland and Delaware Railroad Company, said she believed the train operators did everything required when approaching the crossing. Hurlock Chief of Police Bruce Jones said no further details, including the truck driver’s identity, could be released at that time.

title: Church outside Trappe struck by lightning; storms cause other minor damages
author: Konner Metz
content: Storms on Tuesday across Maryland struck Faith Chapel United Methodist Church east of Trappe with lightning, igniting a fire that caused about $25,000 in damage but no injuries, according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal. Rev. Gary Moore said the damage is "very, very significant" for the small church, and later said, "I was there last night," and added, "Assessing the building will be a difficult decision as we move into the future." He also noted, "It's what makes living in Talbot County a joy," as the Trappe Volunteer Fire Company, aided by neighboring departments, extinguished the blaze in roughly 20 minutes and will host displaced Sunday services at Trappe United Methodist Church on Maple Avenue. Talbot County Emergency Services Director Brian LeCates reported 24 storm‑related incidents, stating, "We had a total of 24 incidents that were storm-related," and urging residents to "Prepare your homes for loose objects that will be blowing around," and to "Secure loose objects." Easton Utilities President John Horner said, "Every upgrade we make strengthens our system, reduces outages, and ensures we're prepared to meet growing demands," while flood watches remain in effect for Caroline and Talbot counties.

title: Preston man pleads guilty to attempted murder - CRIME
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content: A Preston man, Mark William Thompkins, 25, pleaded guilty on November 1, 2023, to attempted second‑degree murder for the February 17, 2022 stabbing of a 25‑year‑old woman near Holly Park Drive and Gilpin Point Road. According to Caroline County State’s Attorney Sloane Franklin, Thompkins attacked the woman with his fists, then stabbed her neck, fled into the woods where he punctured his own throat, and was subdued after 15 minutes of non‑lethal tactics, including a taser. Both Thompkins and the victim were air‑lifted to the University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center for treatment, and after being found competent to stand trial, Thompkins now faces sentencing. Franklin said he will recommend a 30‑year sentence with all but 15 years suspended, followed by five years of supervised probation and special mental‑health conditions, with sentencing set for February 1, 2024.

title: Chestertown pediatrician closes practice amid allegations of abuse
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content: Julio Ramirez, a 65‑year‑old Chestertown pediatrician, permanently surrendered his Maryland medical license after a state board investigation found he sexually assaulted multiple women, including a mother who was examined while seeking treatment for her child in 2023. In a statement, the plaintiffs’ attorneys Michael J. Belsky and Catherine A. Dickinson said, “As alleged in the Complaint, Dr. Ramirez was a serial abuser of women. Our office is actively investigating these instances of abuse, especially against mothers who were assaulted while the doctor was treating their children. It goes without saying that this behavior is not acceptable, and we intend to hold the doctor accountable for his actions. We encourage anyone with information on these allegations to reach out to us,” Belsky and Dickinson said in an interview with the Kent County News. Ramirez announced the permanent closure of his practice, writing, “It is with a heavy heart that I announce my office has closed permanently. title: A 'crisis' on the shore — animal intake on the rise
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content: Animal shelters on Maryland’s Eastern Shore are experiencing a surge in dog and cat intake, with Talbot Humane reporting a 35% rise in dogs and a 25% rise in cats compared with 2023. “This is a trend we are seeing across the country,” Patty Crankshaw‑Quimby said. “I am the president of Professional Animal Workers of Maryland, the state association of shelters and animal control agencies, and we are seeing crisis level intake in our larger municipalities.” Caroline County Humane Society director Karen Culotta noted the shelter is at 95% capacity and suggested the surge may be economically driven, saying, “For some people, with the cost of vet care going up, with the cost of everything going up, or, since the pandemic, sometimes (people) can't afford to feed their animals or can't afford to get vaccinations, which is required of every cat and dog in the state of Maryland,” Culotta said. “It's very challenging for everybody here.” Both officials called the situation “definitely a crisis here on the Eastern Shore” and urged residents to use spay/neuter programs and consider fostering dogs to help alleviate the pressure.

title: Organizations on the Shore hosts count of people experiencing homelessness
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content: A point‑in‑time count of unsheltered and sheltered homelessness was conducted across the Eastern Shore, with churches, libraries and senior centers participating, and Caroline County alone reported about 142 people on Wednesday. Jimmy Morris, continuum of care housing specialist for Mid‑Shore Behavioral Health, said the count in Dorchester County recorded its highest ever number of people experiencing homelessness, and that large efforts were made to reach this specific population. Ashley Kessinger, continuum care manager at Mid‑Shore Behavioral Health, described the shelter situation, saying, "It's been a crisis," Kessinger said. "Our shelters are completely full, and they stay full all the time. They're all working off of waitlists. They're all trying to find other ways so that people that come to them, don't have to turn them away. But they're just full and we don't have enough." Yvette Robinson, grant manager at Neighborhood Service Center, warned that “The numbers are growing, the resources are not,” Robinson said. “We rely on community partners to try to collaborate so that we can see what's working, what may not be working …we're just trying to get the information out that there are variable resources.” Robinson also noted that since Nov. 24, 2024 the center has distributed 9,000 pounds of food and served over 600 families, most of whom are homeless, and the data will be submitted to HUD to seek grant funding. Kessinger emphasized that homelessness on the shore is stigmatized and diverse, stating, "People think homelessness looks a certain way and we have seen people from all walks of life and it does not look a certain way," Kessinger said. "There's a lot of stigma on the shore about homelessness and some people just don't want to see it. If they come across an encampment or something like that, they just want it to go away. …everyone deserves a chance to have a home."

title: '25 kids should not take this whole city down' - Cambridge council grapples with youth crime in city
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content: At the September 12 Cambridge City Council meeting, residents and officials centered the discussion on juvenile crime, and Lance Cephas, father of Commission President Lajan Cephas and Commissioner Sputty Cephas, warned that “25 kids should not take this whole city down,” noting that law‑abiding children are being punished for the actions of a few. He added, “Because if you send them back home to that same environment, ain’t nothing going to happen,” and emphasized that “We’ve all got to come together” rather than let the council be “controlled by 25 kids.” Mayor Stephen Rideout had vetoed the original juvenile curfew ordinance passed on Aug. 14, leading Sputty Cephas to propose amendments that cut the $100 fine in half to $50, a compromise the mayor agreed to discuss privately. While Commissioner Atkiss pointed out that “$100 is a lot of money for a struggling parent,” the council considered retaining reduced fines as part of the penalty. Presentations by United Way’s Pam Gregory and Let’s Thrive Baltimore’s Lisa Molock highlighted broader socioeconomic factors, and community member Theresa Stafford said, “We need to get serious about fixing the problem of poverty,” linking economic hardship to the city’s crime surge.

title: Firefighters handle major town house blaze in St. Michaels
author: Konner Metz
content: On Saturday at about 1:20 p.m., the St. Michaels Fire Department responded to a fire at a six‑unit townhouse complex on Martingham Circle, requesting a second alarm and drawing roughly 70 firefighters from Talbot, Caroline, Dorchester and Queen Anne’s counties. The Maryland Office of the State Fire Marshal identified an electrical failure in an HVAC system in the attic as the cause, estimating about $1 million in damages. Assistant Chief Phil Jones said two of the six units will be “displaced for some time,” a third unit incurred small fire damage, a fourth suffered water damage and the remaining two were unharmed. He noted the extreme heat made the effort harder, saying, “With the heat, it makes it twice as hard for us,” and adding, “Usually a firefighter can only work five to 15 minutes in the heat” without taking a break, and all firefighters received medical checks and bottled water. Jones praised the volunteer crews and inter‑agency cooperation, stating, “We all work together to complete everything.”

title: Family fights Dunkirk cemetery's plan to move plot
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content: The Moseley family bought two plots at Southern Memorial Gardens in 1989 and later interred several relatives there, including Gloria Moseley, her sister, brother, and husband. The cemetery’s attorney, Kevin Vitelli, responded, "It happens at every cemetery," and continued, "Mistakes were made in 1989. "We have to correct those mistakes," he added, noting that the relocation would be at no cost and that, "nobody has filed any action against the cemetery."
